thread.title: City High has lots to play for ahead of postseason
thread.title_full: City High has lots to play for ahead of postseason

title: City High has lots to play for ahead of postseason
text:
City High has lots to play for ahead of postseason Ryan Murken, rmurken@press-citizen.com 10:24 p.m. CDT October 11, 2015 Buy Photo Iowa City High's Jarod Taylor (16) escapes tackle in the backfield by Cedar Rapids Prairie's Taylor Mehmen (64) during the first half of play on Friday, October 2, 2015 in Cedar Rapids. (Justin Torner/Freelance for the Press-Citizen) (Photo: Press-Citizen File Photo) Buy Photo 
A year ago City High entered the final two weeks of the regular season fighting for a playoff berth. 
That’s not the situation this season: the Little Hawks already have a postseason berth locked up, but City High has made sure its final two regular-season games will be plenty meaningful. 
With a 38-0 win over Burlington last Friday City High (5-2) ran its winning streak to five in a row, remained unbeaten in district play and set up a battle for the District 6 lead against Cedar Rapids Washington on Friday at Bates Field. 
“This is why you do what you do, to have another big ballgame down here at Bates Field is exciting,” City High coach Dan Sabers said. “We talked to the kids on Friday after the game and let them know what a great thing they have done for their school and they should be excited about it and I know they are. 
Friday’s meeting with sixth-ranked Cedar Rapids Washington (6-1, 3-0 district) is the start of a critical and challenging two-week swing to end the regular season for City High. 
Rather than fighting to get into the postseason, the Little Hawks are jockeying for home field, a district title and trying to set themselves up for a postseason push. Football Super 10 stays stagnant ahead of huge Week 8 
Following Friday’s home game with Washington, City High will wrap up the regular season at No. 10 Muscatine (6-1, 2-1). 
“It’s a fun thing and we have to take one at a time, but we have two 6-1 teams here to finish out our district,” Sabers said. “The cream should come to the top that is for sure.” 
The Little Hawks have been perfect following back-to-back losses to Cedar Falls and Bettendorf to open the season. 
City High turned in its most complete effort of the season on Friday against Burlington. 
The Little Hawks rolled up season highs of 469 yards of total offense and 38 points in the win while posting its first shutout in 33 games. 
City High’s last shutout, a 38-0 win over Cedar Rapids Jefferson, came Sept. 14, 2012. 
“I feel good about where we are at and what we are about as a team and how we care about each other,” Sabers said. “We are playing the game right now with a lot of enthusiasm and those are all good things.” 
City High will now prepare for the regular-season stretch that begins with defending Class 4A runner-up Cedar Rapids Washington on Friday. 
The Warriors have won five straight games since a Week 2 loss to Cedar Rapids Kennedy and have outscored three district opponents 127-42. 
“They know what winning championships is all about, they did it last year in the district,” Sabers said. “They present a lot of problems for you, but at the same time I like where we are at.” 
OFFENSIVE PLAYER OF THE WEEK: West High senior Oliver Martin caught five passes for 164 yards and two touchdowns and also returned a punt 67 yards for a score in a 63-27 win over Dubuque Hempstead . 
Martin had touchdown grabs of 65 and 75 yards and averaged 34.5 yards on four punt returns. 
RUNNER-UP: Jared Taylor keeps clicking as the City High starting quarter. The junior completed 11 of 16 passes for 191 yards and two touchdowns in a 38-0 win over Burlington. 
Taylor threw a 44-yard touchdown pass to Charles Johnson and a 34-yarder to Jason Jones as the junior quarterback notched his fourth game of at least two touchdown passes. 
DEFENSIVE PLAYER OF THE WEEK: Erick Fletcher, Charles Johnson, Brady Bigley and every member of the City High defense can share the honor this week. 
The City High defense limited Burlington to 72 total yards and five first downs in a 38-0 win. 
Fletcher, a senior captain, led City High with 3.5 tackles, including one for loss. 
Johnson had two tackles for loss and Bigley picked off a pass for the Little Hawks. 
RUNNER-UP: Lone Tree senior defensive lineman Caleb Feldman had three sacks among his nine tackles in a 35-20 loss to No. 10 Pekin. 
Reach Ryan Murken at 319-339-7369 or rmurken@press-citizen.com and follow him on Twitter at @rmmurken. Read or Share this story: http://icp-c.com/1RBHKqc TOP VIDEOS
